s.text: They need to sell the case that our colossal wage inequality is not a fact of nature; that a progressive labor movement can make our workplaces more decent and more productive; and that strong unions can leverage gains not only for their members but for the broader society.
Several weeks ago I spoke with a New York City organizer about the disastrous newspaper strike in Detroit.

Now, the sight, in 1997, of self-respecting American trade unionists singing a socialist anthem--in however jokey a spirit--would doubtless set off alarm bells.
And then, for uplift and inspiration, a chance to sing "Solidarity Forever" and other anthems that no normal person under the age of 60 has ever heard.
The tactical savvy that Sweeney brings might help stanch the AFL-CIO's bleeding (it's been losing more than 200,000 members a year).
It's easy to imagine Dick Armey and Trent Lott nudging each other with told-you-so glee, or Gore and Gephardt averting their eyes with a shudder.
Making this case won't be easy, but it's unavoidable.
If they want to win a decent contract in Detroit, what they need is a squad of 50 people who will target the boards of directors of Gannett and Knight-Ridder.
You've got to look in the mirror every morning and ask yourself: 'What am I organizing for ?' "
